segments.text: ...with Mike Sullivan by Tammy Lawrence on March 14th concerning the Vietnam War where he more or less had a scenic tour in combat.
In the interesting of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection and University Archives.
Is this all right with you, Mr. Sullivan?
Yes.
Okay.
Can you tell me a little bit about, tell me where you were born and the day of your birth?
I was born in Lubbock, Texas, September the 20th, 1943.
When I was in 11th grade, I'd been to 11 different schools.
My father was killed in World War II.
My mother remarried, and my stepfather started putting in Hertz rental car stations all over Texas and Louisiana.
And I graduated high school in Alamo Garden, New Mexico.
After graduation in 1962,
I went to Texas Tech, graduated there in 1966.
Okay, Mr. Sullivan, can you tell me a little bit about the reasons why you joined the military and the years that you were in service?
My last semester of school, my draft board had tried to get me
tried to draft me three times my last semester before I finished.
And so I was motivated at that point to go into a service that I had little choice about.
And I chose the Army.
He chose the Army.
So after you graduated from school, you volunteered in the service just because they were pressuring you while you were in school to join?
That was partly it.
I was planning on going into the Army anyway.
I didn't really

know what i was going to do in my professional life and i thought it would give me a little time to think about that too were you kind of motivated since your dad fought in world war ii uh oh i guess i was somewhat i guess most men think that the military is just a natural part of their life and you just kind of do that at some time in your life i did anyway
So what year was it that you started?
I joined the Army in 1966.
I enlisted in the Army as a private E-1.
Went to Fort Knox, Kentucky for basic training, advanced armor training.
And then I went to Officer Candidate School.
Graduated from that in May of 67 as an armor officer.
And I went from there down to Fort Polk, Louisiana, to a training company there.
From Fort Polk, I came down to order for Vietnam in 1968.
I went to, before going to Vietnam, I went down to Panama to go to Jungle Warfare Training School.
which was a three-week program.
And then I left there and went on to Vietnam.
And I got there in May of 68.
At the train school in Panama, what kind of train were they training you in?
You said jungle.
Can you go in a little bit more detail?
Well, the canal zone, I believe, is on the 9th.
degree of latitude, which is the same latitude that runs through Vietnam.
So it had the same type of temperament as far as weather and vegetation and climate goes.
So they're trying to get you used to the climate and the weather?
Right, acclimated to the vegetation and
What you need to, it's also a survival type training in case you got out into, you know, a jungle in which you could live off of animals and certain plants and that kind of stuff.
But it was, it ran about 20 hours a day for three weeks of training.
You got about three to four hours to sleep a night, if any.
And you had night operation.
It was all infantry oriented tactics.
Such as?

Which is just, uh, infantry is the ground soldier type, you know, for, uh, like you'd have, say, a class on what you might call like an L-shaped ambush for instance, and this is the way you set it up and you just practice, uh, things like that, uh, you had escape and evasion, uh, training, uh,

all different types of plant and vegetable, what you could eat and couldn't eat, what was poisonous, not poisonous, medicinal plants that were available, how to survive weather-wise, where to get water from, either from plants or from the ground, just survival type stuff.
Did you feel like this training in Panama helped you more in Vietnam than if you hadn't had it?
Yeah, it was real good.
What was probably more realistic than the training was the number of hours that you spent awake a day.
So they had you used to staying up long hours and going out without sleep for a while.
Right.
And what that does, it also kind of trains you.
These were all officers that were down there.
And it kind of trains you.
It shows you what happens to you when you get tired.
And you get a little mentally, you know, pressed a little bit because they really press you during the school.
And so it's the same type of pressures that are there every day in Vietnam.
So you might as well just get used to it.
And if you can see how it affects you, then you're better able to control your people
and understand their situation.
Understand what they're going through and probably have a little concern over them whereas if you didn't understand.
Right.
Okay.
When you got, when you were going besides this training in the field and stuff, they talked to you about the Vietnamese culture such as their religion and the ways they lived over there?
Well, uh,

in your incoming orientation in Vietnam at uh in Long Ben uh they had a a small class on the cultural aspects and the politics a little bit of the region it wasn't very much not very much at all no you're talking about a day a day that's all I told you yeah then you find it quite hard okay let's
Before I get to that question, let's go to, you're on the plane, you went by plane over there, and where did you land?
At Long Bend.
Long Bend.
Yeah.
Can you go on from what you did the first time you got there?
Well, how'd you feel about going over there?
Were you anxious or were you... Well, I think everybody...
You're probably a little apprehensive because it's new, it's unknowing, it's dangerous.
You've heard all the bad things, and you don't know how you're going to react as an individual under a lot of stress.
My consideration was I felt like I wanted to be an officer because
If I was going to get killed, then I'd like to have a little bit to say so about it.
You could determine what you were going to be.
Right.
At least I'd have some say so.
I thought, you know, and if I made a mistake, then it was my mistake and not somebody else's mistake.
And that was one of the things that motivated me to go to OCS.
So what officer, what was your rank?
When I was a first lieutenant in Vietnam,
I was an armor officer.
After I went through the initial incoming orientation there, I was assigned to the 4th Infantry Division up at Pleiku.
And we went to Pleiku, and I was assigned to the 2nd Squadron of 1st Cavalry Regiment.
It's the oldest unit in the United States Army.
The cavalry?
Yeah.
Second and first calf, what they call it.
What did you do there?
When I got for two months, I was the, what they call the S1, assistant S1, which was an administrative type function.
Officers, when they go over there, spent six months in administrative capacities and six months in the field.
So my, normally.
That's kind of the way it broke down.

I got up there, and there again, as a personal preference, I wanted to, there again, if I was going to get killed, I just didn't get killed the first six months as opposed to the last six months, you know, so when I put it off, I worry about it.
Because most of the administrative positions were not that dangerous, you know.
You might be in a
in a base camp somewhere and they, you know, they shoot artillery and, uh, you know, have sapper attacks and stuff like that.
But, uh, it's just kind of chance type stuff.
It wasn't, wasn't really too dangerous at all.
Uh, but part of my duties being in that capacity was I attended the evening briefing for General Stone, who was commanding general at 4th infantry division.
And it was just kind of like you see in the movie.
You got all the maps on the wall.
There are the good guys, the bad guys.
And you got to see how everything, the Army, the Navy, the Air Force, you had special forces, people who had mercenaries that were working in the area.
You had the ROPS, which was the Republic of Korea, how those people functioned in the system.
And you got to see how it all kind of fit together, which I thought was real interesting.
One of the G5 of the 4th Division, which has to do with psychological warfare and civil affairs, their assistant G5 was leaving.
He was leaving country and going to go back to the United States.
So G5 asked me if I wanted to come up and be assistant G5 on general staff.
for the 4th Division.
I said, let me go back and check with my unit.
So I went back and talked to my boss, who was the S-1.
I said, when am I going to get a platoon?
And he said, well, I don't know.
Well, the deal was my boss was from West Point.
All of the officers in this particular unit were from West Point except four.
There's my son.
And S-1?
In the whole unit, the second and first half, everybody in it was from West Point.
And it was...
They kind of resented y'all getting... Well, let's just say they looked after the West Pointers first, and if something else happened, yeah, they'd stick somebody else in there.
Well, there was myself.
I went to Texas Tech, and I was an OCS graduate, and that's how I got my commission.
A guy lived next door to me.
was from Texas A&M.
He got his commission through ROTC.
There was another kid from New York who was in OCS with me.
He was a week ahead of me.
And he got his commission in OCS.
And then there was General Abram's son, John John, who was a couple weeks behind me in OCS.
And he got his commission in ROTC, I mean in OCS.
So we were the only four reserve officers in the unit.
Everybody else was from West Point.
So I asked my boss, when was I going to get a platoon?
He said he didn't really know.
And I said, well, you know, you've had two lieutenants from West Point come in.
So they got their platoon as soon as they got there.
So I've been there longer than them.
And he said, well, that's just the way it is, Lieutenant.
I said, well, fine.
So I went back and talked to the G5 and see if the job was still open.
He said, yes.
And I said, well, I would take it then.
And so I went back and told my boss that I was quitting there.
He said, well, you can't quit.
And I said, yeah.
I said, I can.
I said, I'm going to.
And so, because General Staff calls the shots.
And they are the ultimate authority there.
And so I knew I could get on General Staff.
So I went up and I was Assistant G-5.
Well, my boss, the G-5, was...

air defense artillery officer and he stayed there for another couple of months and then he was replaced and he went back to the states and my new boss was an armored colonel and i walked up to him reported sir lieutenant sullivan and he said who are you i said i possess the g5 he said not for long you're not he said lieutenants belong in the field not on general staffs
So you got to go to the... And, you know, so he said, where'd you come from?
I said, well, second to first cab.
He said, you want to go back there?
I said, no, I don't want to go back there.
You know, I burned some bridges there, and I didn't want to have to go back and have to rebuild.
And he said, well, where do you want to go?
Well, the infantry units had what they called mechanized infantry, which is armored personnel carriers.
and they had infantry people who rode around and armored personnel carriers.
They had 1st and 22nd Infantry, but I didn't want to go there either, because I'd seen too many bad things happen to armored personnel carriers.
Because, I mean, one little mine or something, they blow them apart and nobody survives, you know.
And I just think too much of that, and I didn't want that.
But then there's the 1st and 10th Cav, which is another armored unit, armored Cav unit, which is basically the same thing.
I didn't like that.
And then there's another unit, 1st and 69th Armor, which was straight armor or all tanks.
Well, I like tanks, so I chose the 1st and 69th.
And so I got out, and I was a platoon leader with the 1st and 69th Armor.
And we, at this particular time, we were operating north of Cameron, north of Quignon, up in a place called like the Antelope Valley and around Bongsong and 506 Valley, LZ English.
So you drove tanks?
Right.
I was a tank platoon leader.
I had five tanks and 19 men under my command.
And then we just went around.
I was a
I was attached to the 173rd Airborne.
So, they told me, he said, well, like my first day, he said, well, you're going to be assigned to Charlie Company, 2nd Battalion, 503rd Infantry of the 173rd.
He said, they're in such and such location, go find them.
So I did, and...
How'd you get, I mean, did they fly you, helicopter you into where they were, or were they just real close to you?
Uh, no, from, from the tank unit?
Yeah.
No, we just drove our tanks, you know.
Okay.
What was the scenery around?
Uh, the, the, the terrain, uh, was, uh, kind of mountainous, and, uh, then along the coastal areas was, was kind of, uh,
You know, sandy, beachy type places like you'd see on any beach.
Real pretty, lots of vegetation.
But if you went inland a little bit, then you got into more of the mountainous type area.
Can you tell me what a usual day was like for you?
When I was with this armor unit, I was attached to the 173rd, as I mentioned before.
We did various types of operations.
They had what they called search and rescue, which you may find somebody might be trapped and you go in to help them get out.
They had search and destroy, where you knew that they had either troops, supplies, people that were giving them intelligent information, and you would go out and you would

destroy whatever the situation was uh we did a lot of uh i guess it's kind of like being uh in the police department tell you just visible you know you're out there and it interrupts you know there if they if all of a sudden they see you here and you're over there then they can't really make their plans so you're kind of constantly on the move uh during the daytime uh most of the uh the
actual combat type stuff for us took place at night, usually from about 9 o'clock at night to 3 o'clock in the morning, which are real high critical hours.
And we would, in our night location, we would pull our tanks in, kind of like covered wagon style, and with the front slopes of the tanks at the outside and the main guns that way.
You would have infantry people between the tanks.
and then you had your backs to the inside of the circle.
How big was the circle?
The circle, of course, sometimes depends on how many tanks you had too.
It was hard to keep your tanks repaired.

You were issued five most of the time, probably had an average of three because you were always having to get something fixed on one and you'd have to take back to a base camp and a part would have to be flown in.
So you always had something that was broken.
But let's say if I had five tanks, then probably you're looking at a perimeter or probably would encompass about
60, 80 yards in a circle type, you know, pretty big area.
And that'd probably be the diameter, you know.
And the infantry between them were dug in?
Right, they would dig in at night between each of the tanks, you know.
A normal rifle company of the
Say, like, 173rd calls for, I believe it's 156 men as a full complement of filling every position.
They, too, usually operate on a whole lot less, probably an average of about 85 people, which is what they call a standard company, which was about half staffed.
And most of the times you probably wouldn't have 85 in the origin?
I mean, 85 is probably an average.
You know, 75 to 85 would be what you're going to be playing with.
So what was the action like?
Well, at night, and it's kind of funny, on this first particular day that I've been assigned to the 173rd, infantry people, straight leg infantry types, are real nervous.
You can kind of imagine a cat in a room full of rocking chairs with about a 10-foot tail on them.
That's about what they act like, and
They're real jumpy and all that kind of stuff.
And tanks, these tanks weigh 52 tons apiece.
They make noise.
There's no way you can hide one.
You drive around.
People hear you.
And infantry people are kind of like cats.
They're real quiet.
They don't make a lot of noise.
And when we were with them, they didn't really know what to quite think of us.
because we made so much noise.

Well, the first night that we were with them, tanks have, of course, in 1968, we were just kind of getting into solid state type electronics, but some of the radios still had a lot of tubes in them, and they took a lot of a drain on the batteries.
Well, we had a lot of batteries, but we had to charge the batteries up.
The only way we could do that was to start the tanks at night.
Okay.

I started these tanks up about, you know, midnight, and the company commander of the 173rd came over to me and just went crazy, you know, I've compromised our location, you know, he's getting rid of us tomorrow, he don't want anything to do with us, you know, without crazy or what, you know, giving away our location, that kind of routine.
And he said, I don't want you guys, I'm getting rid of you tomorrow.
I said, well, that's fine, there's always, you know, somebody else to play with, you know.

uh well they just weren't used to us and uh i think that's probably uh common to a lot of situations you know what you don't understand you kind of a little leery of and and uh it just so happened though that the next morning uh uh not saying all the fighting takes place at night but most of it does because
They don't like to just run up against American firepower because it's just devastating.
They couldn't beat it.
That's right, and they're not stupid.
So you just wouldn't want to just go up there and just get your teeth kicked in just because you didn't have anything else to do.
So they used things to their advantage, too, and mainly that was darkness.
But we had a way out for that, too, because all the tanks had what they called xenon searchlights on them, and they had...
200 million candle power, which is, you turn one of those things up at midnight, and it's just like 12 noon in a day.
It's just daytime.

But it had the same infrared capability, so you could do it at night, and you could see at night with infrared without giving away your location, unless they had infrared detectors, which they had those too.
But anyway, it just so happened that the next day we got in a little firefight the next day while we were still with the infantry people.
And, you know, if we catch troops in vegetation, our standard round was what they call a fleshette round.
And it is just so devastating.
They're like little steel arrows, about an inch long.
And it'll clear a path about...
80 meters deep and about 200 meters wide.
If you catch somebody out, they can't get away from it.
They're just caught and blown away.
They're just caught.
They're blown away.
You cannot.
It's just devastating.
You could just clear that path out.
I mean, you just clear it out.
You catch them out in the open, they're just dead ducks.
You may find...
They had another round called a canister round, which is the same thing.
It's kind of like, if you can imagine, a bunch of steel rods that are just packed down about 18 inches and then sliced up like little beanie weenie type of deals.
You know, a big weenie sliced up like a big little weenie, about as thick as your little finger.
And those things, you could be in real thick vegetation, you could pop one of those, and you used to have instant daylight.
I mean, it's just, it's just so powerful.
But anyway, we got in this firefight,
And we leaped on top of those guys, you know, in just one way.
And then the infantry company commander thought, well, that's maybe not so bad, you know.
Let those suckers go out and get them, you know.
We'll just have them back and look.
And, of course, we weren't, you know, it was not really any big deal to us.
So, anyway, they decided they, you know, would keep us.
They'd hang around a little bit, you know.
And after a while, I remember...
One time, my troops, the armor people, have to be supported.
They have to have fuel.
They have to have diesel fuel.
They have to have ammunition.
They have to have parts.
We might have to pull an engine out in the middle of the jungle somewhere.
They had kind of like a big wrecker called a VTR, like a big wrecker on tracks with a great big boom on it, and we'd pull transmissions.
We pulled engines, fixed them in the field, you know, which makes you vulnerable while you're doing that.
But sometimes that happens, and you have to go and make do.
But anyway, after I'd been there for about, oh, I guess a couple weeks, well, actually after about a week, I figured out that, you know, whoever you're attached to in the Army, the rule is,
that if I'm attached to you, then you have to provide support for me.
But I could see after just a few days that the 173rd was just not equipped to support a tank platoon.
And so I just started having to provide my own support.
Well, in doing that, I thought, well, I'll just go ahead and take care of them, too, because we all used the same weapons.
I could order the ammunition, everything special that they had.
that I couldn't get for them was like 81 millimeter mortar ammunition.
But all the rest of it I could get for them.
But I remember we were up in a valley called the 506 Valley, which just had to be a road number on a map.
And we were sitting up on top of this hill.
And I had gone ahead and ordered food, an evening meal.
Normally, we got...
in armor, we would get one hot meal a day.
Infantry guys, I know guys that had been there that never had a hot meal the whole time they were there.
They were lucky to even have food.
They ate from these cans?
Yeah, they'd have C-rations or what they call LERP rations, which were dehydrated type food, and you'd add a little water.
How'd y'all get hot meals?
Okay.
This particular incident, I had called in and said,
I want food for 200 people, I mean 100 people.
They brought it out on a little deal called a 5-4-A, which is like a pickup on tracks, wheels and tracks.
Anyway, this little deal is coming across the ground out there.
Of course, my platoon, we're just like a
bunch of old hogs, you know.
The guy set up all the food.
I'm talking about roast beef, mashed potatoes, gravy, jello with lettuce, you know, and cold milk and chocolate pudding.
And these guys, these infantry guys sitting over there watching all this stuff, or my guys, leap down on top of it like they're used to.
You know, one waits for the other, got real good manners, like one hog waits for another.
And so...
And I just grabbed my plate, and that's, you know, after my guys got theirs.

And finally, I thought I had mentioned it to the company commander that I was going to order food for, but I guess I forgot to because he came over to me and asked the lieutenant, he said, looks like you have a little bit left there.
You think some of my people could get a bite of that?
I said, oh, yeah, I'm sorry, I forgot.
I must not have told you.
I said, I'll order food for you guys, too.
I said, yeah, you can line the suckers up, you know.
And so I did, which is the first hot meal most of those guys have ever had.
since they had been in country.
And how were y'all able to get those males in?

Well, we had a forward fire base, what's called a fire base, that was set up in a place close to what's called LZ English, which is just north between Da Nang and Cameron Bay, kind of halfway in the middle there.
And it was just a place where they resupplied those people and where you could work on your tanks if you needed to.
There's a lot of administration that goes on in any type of military unit.
So that was kind of the forward base camp.
But anyway, those guys, after they got that hot meal,
You know, they thought that they kind of liked us after that for a while, you know.
And most of those guys, I wish I had my pictures because I could show you and talk at the same time.
But most of those guys, I mean, there's no fat on them at all.
They're sleek because all they do is walk and not eat very well, you know, and sweat a lot.
But anyway, I kind of fattened them up there a little bit.
But anyway, I started carrying it.
Their normal rucksacks probably weigh anywhere from 55 to 80 pounds that they strap on their backs.
And they probably hike an average of 15 clicks a day, 15 kilometers a day, which is about 11 miles.
And all they do is walk around out there.
So I started humping their rucks for them and carrying their mortars for them.
getting their food, their ammunition, their mail, everything I was getting for them.
And they, after a while, you know, they just really didn't like us.
You know, because then I really kind of spoiled them because I just started carrying them.
They'd just hop on the back of the tank.
Yeah, the tanks looked like a bunch of Sooners from Oklahoma heading to California back during the Depression.
And it was almost comical what we looked like, I'm sure, to other people, but beats walking.
And they kind of thought it did, too.
While y'all were moving, were y'all with those people in your tank?
Was it snipers by each other?
Oh, yeah, you'd have stuff like that.
Usually, you kind of knew what to expect most of the time.

You know because you'd have intelligence reports that you know the bad guys over here in this area you go find them go get them you know, and you just kind of just hunt them down like a covey of quail and You know just track them down and get rid of them and We did some joint operations with the Vietnamese National Police We did some joint operations with with other Vietnamese armored units and
and areas all over the coastal area.

After I, after I'd been with them for a couple months, MACV, which was the Military Assistance Command Vietnam, which was the political arm of the Army, started levying all the USRV units, which is the United States Army regular units, United States Army
Vietnam, which was the American fighting units, they started sending out orders to those guys saying, we want you to send us captains, lieutenants, and E7s.
And they formed 350 of what they called mobile advisory teams.
And some genius had finally decided that if they were going to win this deal, there was going to have to be one at the grassroots level or at the little village level.
The Vietnamese army had just a horrendous AWOL rate.
And they decided to quit fighting.
They left and they went home for a while, you know.
They weren't disciplined.
Well, it's not that they weren't disciplined.
It's just they've already been doing this 20 years, you know.
So if you're going to save your family, you've got to just take off every once in a while.
So, I mean, you never knew what you were going to be left with with those people.
And that was kind of a bad thing for Americans to do.
adapt to because you're used to thinking, well, I've got so much, and this is what I'm going to deal with.
You find out you don't have that.
So I got, in order to be chosen for one of these mobile advisory teams, you had to have had at least four months in country, and you had to have at least four months left in country.
so they could get a little mileage out of you.
So they didn't want to just take the green troops and throw them into a deal that would probably be disastrous.
And then they didn't, you know, if you're going to be leaving next week, it wouldn't be a good idea either, you know.
So they formed 350 of these mobile advisory teams, and they sent us to a school down in Zeon, which is just outside of Saigon.
And we had...
to get completely retrained on all new weapons, which was M1 rifles, M1 and M2 carbines, 60mm mortars, and BARs, which was Browning Automatic Rifles.
All these weapons were all leftovers from World War II.
And that's what we had given the South Vietnamese to use, where a standard American would have an M16 as his rifle.
So y'all were using this all the time?
Right.
Well, it's not that I still use the M16, but, and of course I supplied my own self, took care of all my own supplies.
And, but, but the Vietnamese units had the old equipment, you know, 30 caliber machine gun.
Of course, in our infinite wisdom of our government and so many things that they did over there, it's just one stupid blunder after another.
they give a Vietnamese soldier an M1 rifle that weighs 9 12 pounds, and if he's got it sitting on the ground, the butt of the rifle on the ground, it hits him somewhere between his chin and his ear.
So it'd be kind of like somebody giving your eye a flagpole and say, you know,
This is your weapon.
Well, it's too long and it's too big, you know, and it just about pulls them over.
Time to get it up.
It weighs so much, you know, it's hard for them to use.

But they liked the little M1, M2 carbines, but they were in such poor condition, you could sit there and shake them and the bolt would fall out, which is a receiving bolt, you know, which seats the bullet when it goes in and out.
It was just a terrible deal.

But the idea behind the mobile advisory team was to go out and round up all the males in the villages where these people lived, and equip them, and train them, and then go out on operations with them.
So they gave us, we had 35 hours, 35 classroom hours of Vietnamese language.
And they said, now go train an army.
Now, that's a real hopeful situation, you know.
And in my particular situation, they sent us up to a little town called Bami Tut, which is about 10 miles this side of Cambodia.
This particular town was the capital of all the Montagnard people, which are kind of like Indians in the United States.
They don't speak Vietnamese.
And you're trained in Vietnamese?
Yeah.
Well, you had half Vietnamese and half Montagnards.
Well, you know, the French had been over there for 20 years, and some of them spoke a little French.
And, you know, you can't help but live someplace with no few words, and so some of them spoke a little Vietnamese.
And of course, the Americans had been there for a while, so some of them knew a little English.
And so I actually bought a French book, a little paperback French book.
And with that and a little English and a little Vietnamese.
And the particular people I was around was a tribe that spoke what they called Rade Montagnard.
It's kind of like Apache or Navajo or something like that.
So I got this guy to teach me, write down a bunch of words that I felt like I needed and how to speak those words.
And so I just memorized all those words in Rite A.
So with a little bit of Rite A, a little bit of French, a little bit of English, and a little bit of Vietnamese, we could communicate that and draw lots of pictures in the dirt.
So language there is a big factor.
Big factor.
Of course, here you got America.
Again, they give me an interpreter, right?
Now, how do we as Americans, you know, if we want to find out if you know anything, what do we do?
We stick a pencil in their hand and we give them a test, right?
You know what we do?
Well, my little interpreter, you know, that's real good.
He could translate on paper, dog.
you know, in English to dog in Vietnamese, and get them, you know, back and forth, but he couldn't speak.
He couldn't speak it at all?
Very little.

So, and he used to get me in a lot of trouble, because, of course, you know, I would say things, and he would kind of think he understood what I was saying, and he would say things, because I'm a village chief,
You know, and boy, I could tell Vilshi all of a sudden, like he's insulted, you know.
And I said, you know, come on.
I said, what did you tell him?
You know, I told him, I said, no, that's not right.
That's not what I meant.
You know, so he had some real communication problems.
Yeah, it was bad.
But this was, but what we would do is we would teach these people infantry tactics, which is ground, you know, type tactics.
tactics, and then we'd go out on operations with them.
I had five regional force companies and ten regional, what they call popular force platoons, which is just kind of rounded up everybody in a small village, and they call them a popular force platoon.
So I had ten of those little platoons and five companies.
The companies usually would guard a stationary object like a bridge or radio station,
electric power generating station, you know, something like that.
They would have a mission to do something.
The little popular force type guys, they were just kind of supposed to defend themselves, be intelligence gathering people out there for us, but yet they would go in operations with us too.
Sometimes we'd have a joint operation, we'd pull in a bunch of platoon, a couple companies, and you'd go out and do your thing that day.
Tell me a little bit about the action that you were involved in with the infantry.
Okay.
Kind of like describe the scenery and how you...
I was up in an area in what they call a two-corps.
Vietnam was broken down into four different corps.
There was I-Corps, which that was mainly...
The Marines were up north.
2 Corps was kind of a mountainous type region.
3 Corps was kind of between the mountainous up to about Saigon.
And 4 Corps was kind of all of the Delta area where it was all rivers and all that kind of stuff.
Lots of water, lots of rice paddies.
There's rice paddies all over the country, but I'm talking about just all rice paddies, you know.
Just all water.
I wasn't down south, I was kind of in the north to north central portion of Vietnam, mostly mountain type terrain, lots of vegetation.
There was a lot of coffee, tea, rubber plantations, lots of bananas, pineapples, that kind of plants growing around the area, even on a commercial basis.

One of the really frustrating things for, I guess, everyone that was over there, kind of standing order was that if you got shot at from a coffee-tear rubber plantation, you were not allowed to shoot back into these plantations because you were liable to damage a plant, you know.
And it takes three years to grow a tea bush to maturity, you know,
And so apparently our government felt like that the three-year-old T. Bush was a whole lot more valuable than some 19, 20-year-old kid, which was kind of frustrating if it was you, you know.
What did y'all do?
You just couldn't fire back?
You just had to sit there while they fired at you?
Yeah, or leave, you know.
That was usually like in daytime operations.
There again...
I thought one of the more civilized things that I found when I was in Vietnam was that basically from about one o'clock in the afternoon to about three or four, it would just kind of cease fire.
I mean, it just kind of, you know, take a siesta, let's call this thing off for a while, everybody kings eggs, and nothing ever happened.
Yeah, everybody just says, let's just rest up for tonight, you know, or, you know, you've done your thing for the morning, well, hit it again tonight, and, you know, have a little lunch, and,
You know, just kind of rest for a while.
So it was kind of weird, some of the things that went on over there.
You had asked earlier about what it felt like about the first time that somebody had shot at you and that kind of atmosphere.
I was kind of, I guess, probably like everybody else.
You don't know how you're going to react.
You know, can I shoot that guy?
I don't even know him, you know.
You kind of have those thoughts.
You think about that before, but the first time somebody shot at me, there was no doubt in my mind that I could pull the trigger and did.
It's just automatic.
Oh, yeah, it's just automatic.
You know, when you're sitting here in the United States, it's real fine to have some real high ideals and, of course, conscientious objectors,
Back in the mid-60s, it was kind of a big deal.
The press gave it a lot of notoriety and that kind of stuff.
It was my experience, without exception, every conscientious objector that I ever met, most of whom were talked into by their recruiter, said, well, you don't want to carry a weapon.
No, I wouldn't want to kill anybody in it.
So their recruiters would say, well, then you're saying you would like to help people.
Is that what you're trying to say?
Oh, yeah.
Then you'd like maybe some medical field.
Would that be good?
They'd say, well, yeah, that'd probably be fine.
And so they would make them combat medics.
Well, little did they know what the combat medic does.
It isn't a hospital.
It isn't a mass unit.
You're out there with the infantry.
And when you have these nice, fine ideas,
in the United States, it's awful easy to stand on a soapbox and spout them off.

But when that other side doesn't know about your fine ideas, and you don't have the protective aspects of the continental United States, and you're a congressman, and you're a senator at the right home if something doesn't please you, I mean, that'd kill you.
And all of a sudden, you understand the real world as opposed to the more idyllic world of liberty.
